body:
@pshivkumar From an initial look, what you are doing sounds reasonable. Although, ingesting 50 GB of data into Hudi should take no less than 15-30 mins in an average case. We will need a little more information to help you debug the problem : 

1. Can you take a screenshot of the `stages` tab in your Spark UI. Essentially, I'm interested to see what's the shuffle in your stages.
2. Can you tell me how many executors you used to run this ? If you look at the spark properties you linked, the `spark.executor.instances` field doesn't have a value. If you are relying on YARN, the default is 1 executor. You can also see the number of executors by clicking on the executors tab in the Spark UI.
3. Can you please share the hoodie configs ?

On a side note, if you are just trying to import your dataset into hudi format, look at this : https://hudi.apache.org/migration_guide.html#approach-2

@n3nash Below is the stage info after job ran about 22 hours. I looked at parquet importer approach. Can I use this for datasets that have composite keys (I am using custom key generator in my current hudi job)?

1. Attached screenshot of stages tab.
![screen shot 2019-02-21 at 10 34 09 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47641088/53192982-a46d4f00-35c4-11e9-8883-493e0f844231.png)
2. I ran with 20 executors. Excel file I gave has that value but that is hiding on the right end of cell. Below is screenshot of executor tab.
![screen shot 2019-02-21 at 10 26 21 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47641088/53193076-f1512580-35c4-11e9-8255-cc7bc267bdb5.png)
3. Hoodie Configs:
    val writer = data.write.format("com.uber.hoodie")
      .option("hoodie.insert.shuffle.parallelism",parallelism) --set to 1000
      .option("hoodie.upsert.shuffle.parallelism",parallelism) --set to 1000
      .option(DataSourceWriteOptions.RECORDKEY_FIELD_OPT_KEY, primaryKey)
      .option(DataSourceWriteOptions.PRECOMBINE_FIELD_OPT_KEY, pkOrderingCol)
      .option(HoodieWriteConfig.TABLE_NAME, tableName)
      .option(DataSourceWriteOptions.HIVE_TABLE_OPT_KEY, tableName)
      .option(DataSourceWriteOptions.HIVE_SYNC_ENABLED_OPT_KEY, enableHiveSync)
      .option(HoodieCompactionConfig.CLEANER_FILE_VERSIONS_RETAINED_PROP, 1)
      .option(HoodieCompactionConfig.CLEANER_POLICY_PROP,"KEEP_LATEST_FILE_VERSIONS")
      .mode(insertMode)
      .option(DataSourceWriteOptions.HIVE_PARTITION_EXTRACTOR_CLASS_OPT_KEY, "com.uber.hoodie.hive.NonPartitionedExtractor")
       .option(DataSourceWriteOptions.KEYGENERATOR_CLASS_OPT_KEY, "horizonHudiCompactor.HorizonKeyGenerator")
@bvaradar Addressed some of your comments and left comments for others. PTAL
@n3nash @bvaradar @vinothchandar PTAL.

@pshivkumar Yes, the `HDFSParquetImporter` tool only takes a single value `_row_key`, but you can easily change the tool to support composite keys, happy to take a PR from you :)

Additionally, I see that the input size for each of your batch is around `225 GB` which is larger than what we thought earlier (45GB) for stage 419 whereas for stage 463 it correctly shows 46.6 GB, can you tell me what's the different between these batches ? (look at the `mapToPair` stage to show the actual input size). 20 executors may not be enough to finish your job quickly, you may want to bump that up to around 100. 

Also, in the executors tab, for some reason I see `Active 531` executors whereas only 20 entries are there. Not sure what's going on there.

I also see there's a lot of shuffle due to BloomIndex. @vinothchandar Is there a way to avoid these shuffles ?
Please add me too, k.zarzycki@gmail.com
lgtm.. thanks for the contribution..

@AndrewKL Great to see this effort and thanks for summarizing the issues that you are facing. Let's try to dig a little further into each of these : 

1. Performance Bug -> Have you tried to run a comparison of a non-hudi dataset (just a plain hive table for example) on HDFS vs S3 ? I'd like to understand if there's an inherent slowness of HDFS vs S3.

2. Just to be clear, is the EMRFs an issue with EMRFileSystem initialization and not Hudi ?

3. The intermittent issue is a good catch. The problem is due to this line [https://github.com/uber/hudi/blob/master/hoodie-client/src/main/java/com/uber/hoodie/io/HoodieCreateHandle.java#L156](here). Since S3 is eventually consistent, sometimes, the filegetstatus(..) does not find the path and throws this exception. We have consistency checks for S3 at the end of the write before publishing the commit, this is a corner case and should be addressed. Could you please open a bug for this ?

4. Although the exception you see is due to `concurrent modification`, the underlying issue is likely different, seems like a Kryo serlialization issue when serializing array list types (a known issue with kryo). Are you running your spark job with serializer as Kryo ? Check this out : https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/tuning.html#data-serialization. Does this not happen consistently ?

@never-summer Yes, that is the correct way to enable a file based schema provider. 
Hudi is now Apache incubating here : https://github.com/apache/incubator-hudi
Please help fix the documentation there by following the instruction starting here : https://hudi.apache.org/contributing.html#website. 
Please also subscribe to the dev@hudi.apache.org mailing list to get faster responses.

@rchamarthi A similar issue was pointed out here : https://github.com/uber/hudi/issues/586. Please pass the following argument `--schemaprovider-class com.uber.hoodie.utilities.schema.FilebasedSchemaProvider` if you are using a schema provided in a file.
Please go through with this change and the complete setup and if you still have questions can answer them.

Seeing the error log and the code that throws the error, we decided to apply this particular commit: https://github.com/uber/hudi/commit/639c287cab4876f3b5951e5bcd7d4e940f16223f , rebuild the hudi jar, and deployed it on our presto cluster. We have been monitoring our cluster for 7 days and the error never appeared again.

Our guess (really, just a guess) is that this issue is caused by some kind of unclean thread shutdown from a killed or stopped query, causing FSDataInputStream to still be opened to HDFS and causing any hudi query submitted the next time to always get the error. Just to confirm our report before, the issue is intermittent in a sense that: the first error might appear intermittently (we cannot predict the time it appears the first time), but once it appeared, any hudi query submitted after will always get the same error. After this point, the only way to solve it is to restart our presto coordinator. So for example:
````
12.00: the presto cluster is up after restarted 
12.00 - 12.30: any hudi query always succeeded 
12.31: the first error appeared
12.31 - 12.45: any hudi query always threw the error
12.45: restarted the presto coordinator, and presto cluster is up again.
12.45 - ...: any hudi query always succeeded 
and the loop continue.
````
Answering @n3nash 's question regarding the hadoop fsck, yes. We have done hadoop fsck command targeting the folder that contains the data and metadata partition file, and the result has always been HEALTHY. We did this both before and after the issue appeared on the presto cluster.

Many thanks to @n3nash and @vinothchandar for taking the time to look into this issue, and @bhasudha along with @vinothchandar for the commit.

I'll leave it here in case someone else encounter the same problem in the future.

@rahuledavalath :  As mentioned in https://github.com/uber/hudi/blob/687395e40f71f12f130640a9db048bea77a20d8c/hoodie-common/src/main/java/com/uber/hoodie/common/table/log/HoodieLogFormatWriter.java#L236

this is a corner case when spark retries a failed task too quickly before the lease is yielded or when the data-node expires.  In the case, Hudi append retries for 10 times before giving up.

> Could you describe the scenario where the current placement of the code block is not helping you in the PR? Plus an informative commit message along the same lines would help understand what's being fixed, since it so subtle.

HoodieMergeHandle uses SpillableMap. Get here will return the record from either DiskBasedMap or from InMemoryMap. In case of records returned from DiskBasedMap we are creating records everytime where as if it returned from InMemoryMap then we are returning cached record. In case of our hoodie dataset we can have duplicates in single parquet file. So the problem we see is that if same record is getting updated multiple times (and is cached in InMemoryMap) then it fails with assertion in "record.setCurrentLocation(" as it tries to update that more than once.

Above fix is trying to handle duplicate records in single partition case.
- If duplicates are in single parquet (fix in MergeHandle) then both needs to be updated.
- If duplicate records are in different parquet then also both needs to be updated.

> Top level question is : can kryo serialize everything java serialization can? This looks self contained and kryo would be more efficient.. But are there tradeoffs here, we are making

Kryo can serialize all objects. Infact it also allows us to specify serializers for individual classes if we want to avoid using Kryo's default FieldSerializer.

Only catch here is that in case of Java serialization it uses writeObject() & readObject() apis if you have overridden one. Kryo will not use those apis for serde. But if we really want kryo to use them then we can always register this class to use instead JavaSerializer() using "spark.kryo.registrator" spark config.

Details of kryo serialization performance are here. https://github.com/EsotericSoftware/kryo

@NetsanetGeb Hudi is registered as an external table in Hive. Hudi controls the mechanism of how writes are done to a table (writing to an HDFS location) as well as manages schema evolution via avro and eventually registers a custom InputFormat to allow for snapshot reading of these tables. Thus, the data is controlled and managed by Hudi while the metadata (such as partitions) is managed by Hive. There shouldn't be any difference in the hive meta store for Hudi tables but there are a few general differences between Managed vs External tables such as how drop partitions/tables work. Some details here : https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/Hive/Managed+vs.+External+Tables
